question: What force keeps the planets in orbit around the Sun?

content.source_1: The Sun’s mass exerts a gravitational force on every planet, pulling each planet toward the Sun’s center at all times.
content.source_2: Sustained orbital motion requires a continuous inward (centripetal) force toward the central body; without such a force, a body would move off in a straight line.
content.source_3: The Sun generates a large-scale magnetic field, and the interplanetary magnetic field carried by the solar wind permeates the entire solar system.
content.source_4: Magnetic forces act strongly on moving electric charges; in space, plasmas and charged particles can be guided and trapped by magnetic fields, following spiral paths around field lines.
content.source_5: Electromagnetic interactions are vastly stronger than gravity at the scale of particles, and in many space environments they dominate the motion of charged matter.
content.source_6: Planets such as Earth and Jupiter have ionospheres and magnetospheres filled with charged particles that interact with both planetary and solar magnetic fields.
